An emphatic first-half Patrick Bamford penalty earned Leeds United an important three points at Elland road this afternoon helping the Whites move up to eleventh in the Premier League table against an in form Burnley side; previously unbeaten in their last four games.

Leeds managed to hang on despite a nail biting finale which saw Burnley threaten to nick something late on with chances from substitute Jay Rodriguez, who fired over from close range and then Illan Meslier keeping out a Ashley Barnes's effort at his near post.

In all honesty Bielsa's side should really have had the game done and dusted by the end of the first half with the amount of chances they created in a game they started exceptionally well, showing an enormous improvement from the way they started in last weekend's disastrous defeat away at Old Trafford.

Despite their current make shift defence, which has been forced upon them due to the amount of defensive injury's they have at the moment, Leeds looked creative and assured on the ball from the off and it took just three minutes for the home side to take the lead much to the relief of their fans at home watching.

In very unlike Bielsa fashion, Luke Ayling played a long ball over the top leaving the Burnley defence for dead, putting Bamford straight in on goal before being clattered by the on coming Nick Pope, resulting in the referee Robert Jones pointing to the spot.

Bamford confidently stepped up and smashed the ball in to the top right corner of the net leaving the Burnley keeper with no chance, one can only imagine the noise of Elland road had the fans been present .

The home side nearly extended their lead straight away with some fine attacking football from the lively Brazilian Raphinha who slid the ball through to Alioski who only had to square the ball to one of his team mates in the box but the Macedonian international failed to find any one with his cross, instead firing high and wide into an empty stand.

Leeds continued to dominate the possession in the first half with Burnley struggling to cope with their high press and energetic style.

They very nearly added a second when Raphinha pounced on some lack lustre Burnley defending, teeing the ball up nicely for Jack Harrison, who really just had to compose himself and place his shot in to one of the corners but he failed to do so, hitting his shot straight at the Burnley keeper from about six yards out.

It's those types of missed chances that will frustrate the Leeds fans because they know their side need to be a lot more clinical at this level and if that chance goes in they could have then go in at the break with a two nil cushion.

Despite their first-half dominance there were a few scares for the West Yorkshire side, I don't think many Leeds fans would disagree with me if I said they had their hearts in their mouths every time their side conceded a set piece or corner during the match.

Meslier will probably have counted himself a touch fortunate when the referee sided with him and awarded a free kick rather then let Ashley Barnes goal stand, a decision the away fans may have felt a bit aggrieved by.

England midfielder Kalvin Phillips played superbly in his new sweeper role today, dropping in deep between Ayling and Struijk, dealing with absolutely everything that came his way as did Patrick Bamford up top, proving to be a real handful for the Burnley centre backs.

Luke Ayling and Stuart Dallas continued to prove their Premier league stature and once again showed just how important their versatility is for Marcelo Bielsa's team.

In the second-half Burnley looked a totally different team and pressured the home side for the first fifteen minutes after break, surprisingly even dominating the possession as they unsuccessfully searched for a equaliser.

Bielsa made some good changes, bringing on both Pablo Hernandez and Ian Poveda, two players both very good in possession and at retaining the ball at a time when Burnley were dominating the play.

Academy graduate Jamie Shakleton also offered some fresh legs in the later stages replacing a tired looking and low in confidence Mateusz Klich.

After such an impressive start to the season the Polish international looks like he could do with a rest and would perhaps be grateful if his manager brought in another midfielder or two to provide cover for him as the season goes on.

As the game went on there was one last opportunity for Leeds to grab a second goal when their little Spanish magician Hernandez found himself in a 4 v 2 scenario on the edge of the Burnley box after a quick break from a corner but his shot just lacked the finesse it needed to find its way into the bottom right corner.

If he had converted the chance it would of eased the nerves of the fans in the nail biting dying moments of the game and put the icing on the cake on a important result for the team considering the amount of first team players out of action in what is already a very thin squad in comparison to most other teams in the league.

Marcelo Bielsa deserves a huge amount of credit for the job he is doing and for where Leeds United are currently placed in the league at this stage in the season going in to the new year.

Todays win will be crucial for Leeds going forward and I'm sure their fans will have been over moon watching Kalvin Phillips and Luke Ayling keep former striker Chris Wood in their back pockets all afternoon on a day the Australian international and former left-back Charlie Taylor returned to Elland road.
